newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait Oil Tanker Co Q1 profit up 66 pct - official.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait Oil Tanker Co Q1 profit up 66 pct - official.

text.p: State-owned Kuwait Oil Tanker Co (KOTC) said on Tuesday its net profit for the first quarter of the fiscal year 1996/97 (July-June) rose 66 percent to some 4.0 million dinars ($13.3 million).

"Our net profit for the first quarter is about four million dinars," KOTC deputy chairman Sheikh Salman al-Sabah told reporters at a ceremony to award South Korea's Hyundai Heavy Industries Co a contract to build two crude tankers.
KOTC, the shipping arm of the Kuwait Petroleum Corp (KPC) which runs the Gulf state's oil sector, made a net profit of 2.4 million dinars in the same period of the previous year, he said.
"We expect our net profit (for 1996/97) to be about 16 million dinars."
KOTC's net profit fell 0.8 percent to 8.5 million dinars in the 1995/96 fiscal year.
Sheikh Salman said the profit rise stems mainly from "improved shipping prices" and "good management."
"The market has started to improve a little," said KOTC chairman Abdullah al-Roumi. "Most of the world tanker fleet is 20 years old."
KOTC, which has sold its older crude tankers, has four crude tankers all of which are less than five years old.
KOTC has a 31-strong fleet which includes 21 oil product tankers with a total capacity of 1.6 million tonnes and four crude tankers with a combined capacity of 1.1 million.

According to the deal with Hyundai Heavy Industries Co, KOTC will take delivery of two 309,000 tonne tankers in mid-1998. Both tankers conform with U.S. environmental regulations on tankers specifications.
Roumi said the company has no short-term plans to build any more crude tankers, but it is considering a project to build more than one 80,000 tonne oil products tankers.
